title: Is it a red flag that the man I am dating won't speak to me over an NFL game?
opening_message: I'm feeling really confused and a bit hurt because my boyfriend won't talk to me after his team lost to mine in a big game, and I'm wondering if I should be concerned about his reaction or just give him some space.

all: I'm in a long-distance relationship with someone who cares deeply about their favorite football team.
My partner's team lost to mine in the playoffs, but I didn't rub it in because I respect him and his feelings.
Despite my restraint, he won't talk to me now, saying he won't until he's ready.
His behavior feels like a red flag to me - punishing me for something as trivial as a football game - and makes me worry about potential relationship problems if we continue dating.
I'm feeling sad and frustrated that his reaction is ruining my enjoyment of our team's victory, and I'm unsure whether to address the issue or wait it out.
I'm prone to overthinking things and wondering if I should speak up about how his behavior is affecting me.
I'm torn between giving him space to "lick his wounds" and telling him that his actions are making me feel sad, worried that he might not be emotionally mature enough for a relationship with me.

turns.content: I'm feeling really confused and a bit hurt because my boyfriend won't talk to me after his team lost to mine in a big game, and I'm wondering if I should be concerned about his reaction or just give him some space.

That sounds frustrating! It's understandable that you're feeling hurt and confused by his silence. Losing can be tough, but it's not okay for someone to take out their emotions on the people they care about.

Can you tell me more about what happened when he found out your team won? Did he say anything specific or just stop talking to you altogether?

"Actually, he didn't say anything specific at first. He just stopped responding to my texts and calls. It was like I'd done something wrong, even though it was just a game. And now that you mention it, his behavior does feel like a red flag - like he's not okay with me being happy or successful in some way."

That must have been really hurtful and confusing for you! It sounds like he may be projecting his own feelings of disappointment onto you, rather than dealing with them directly. That can be a sign of immaturity.

How do you think this might affect your relationship if things don't change? Are there other times when his reactions feel controlling or possessive to you?

"Man, it's like, yeah, I can totally see what you're saying about him being immature and all that. But honestly, it's hard not to take it personally when someone reacts like that. And it's even harder because we're supposed to be having a good time celebrating our team's win together... now it feels like the whole thing is tainted by his negativity. I don't know, maybe I'm just trying to hold on to some positive vibes, but it feels like he's sucking the joy out of everything."

I totally get what you mean! It's natural to feel hurt and frustrated when someone reacts negatively to your success, especially when you're trying to celebrate together. It sounds like his behavior is really affecting your mood and overall experience.

What do you think would need to happen for you to feel okay about celebrating again? Would it take a conversation with him, or some space and time to reflect on the situation?

"I don't know, it's like... I want to give him space because I don't want things to escalate into a bigger fight, but at the same time, I need to express how his behavior is affecting me. I'm worried that if I don't address it now, it'll just keep happening and we'll never be able to celebrate together without drama."

You're caught between giving him space and wanting to have a conversation about what's going on. It's understandable to worry about escalating the situation into a bigger fight.

How do you think he would respond if you did talk to him about how his behavior is affecting you? Do you think he'd be willing to listen and understand your perspective, or do you feel like he might just shut down again?

I think if I brought it up with him, he'd probably just get defensive and shut down again. Like, I know he's still processing the loss, and I don't want to add fuel to the fire. But at the same time, a part of me wants to have that conversation because I feel like we're avoiding talking about what's really going on here.

It sounds like you're caught between wanting to have an open and honest conversation with him, but also not wanting to stir up more drama or tension.

What would happen if you did decide to talk to him, but instead of focusing on the specifics of his behavior, you focused on how it's affecting your relationship and your own feelings? Would that be a way to approach the conversation without getting too caught up in his emotions?

" Yeah, that makes sense. I guess what's holding me back is worrying that it'll escalate into some kind of argument or he'll just dismiss everything I say. But at the same time, I don't want to let his behavior go unchecked and make me feel like I'm walking on eggshells around him."

It sounds like you're worried about having a big blowout fight, but you also know that ignoring the issue won't make it go away.

How do you think things would be different if you could have a calm and respectful conversation with him about how his behavior is affecting your relationship? Would that help you feel more confident in speaking up?

I think if we could have a calm and respectful conversation about this stuff, it would be huge for me. I'd feel like I'm not just yelling into the void, you know? But yeah, even thinking about bringing it up makes my stomach turn because I know how he reacts when I try to talk to him about this kind of thing - shuts down completely.

I totally get what you mean! It's scary to think about rocking the boat and not knowing how someone will react.

What would be one small step you could take towards having that conversation, even if it feels daunting? Would it be as simple as choosing a quiet moment when you're both calm, or is there something else you could do to prepare yourself for talking to him about this?

Man, yeah... I think choosing that quiet moment when we're both calm would be a good start. Maybe even just having some alone time before talking to him about this, so I can gather my thoughts and not feel like I'm getting caught off guard. And honestly, it'd help if I could figure out what exactly I want to say beforehand, so I don't come across as wishy-washy or unsure of myself.
